text:
How doth the city sit solitary, that was full of people!
how is she become as a widow!
she that was great among the nations,
and princess among the provinces,
how is she become tributary!
speaker: Narrator

text:
She weepeth sore in the night,
and her tears are on her cheeks:
among all her lovers she hath none to comfort her:
all her friends have dealt treacherously with her,
they are become her enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Judah is gone into captivity because of affliction,
and because of great servitude:
she dwelleth among the heathen,
she findeth no rest:
all her persecutors overtook her between the straits.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ways of Zion do mourn,
because none come to the solemn feasts:
all her gates are desolate:
her priests sigh,
her virgins are afflicted,
and she is in bitterness.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And from the daughter of Zion
all her beauty is departed:
her princes are become like harts that find no pasture,
and they are gone without strength before the pursuer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem remembered in the days of her affliction
and of her miseries
all her pleasant things that she had in the days of old,
when her people fell into the hand of the enemy,
and none did help her:
the adversaries saw her,
and did mock at her sabbaths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem hath grievously sinned;
therefore she is removed:
all that honoured her despise her,
because they have seen her nakedness:
yea, she sigheth, and turneth backward.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The adversary hath spread out his hand
upon all her pleasant things:
for she hath seen that the heathen
entered into her sanctuary,
whom thou didst command
that they should not enter into thy congregation.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Is it nothing to you,
all ye that pass by?
behold, and see if there be any sorrow
like unto my sorrow,
which is done unto me,
wherewith the Lord hath afflicted me
in the day of his fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From above hath he sent fire into my bones,
and it prevaileth against them:
he hath spread a net for my feet,
he hath turned me back:
he hath made me desolate
and faint all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The yoke of my transgressions is bound by his hand:
they are wreathed,
and come up upon my neck:
he hath made my strength to fall,
the Lord hath delivered me into their hands,
from whom I am not able to rise up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord hath trodden under foot
all my mighty men in the midst of me:
he hath called an assembly against me
to crush my young men:
the Lord hath trodden the virgin,
the daughter of Judah,
as in a winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For these things I weep;
mine eye, mine eye runneth down with water,
because the comforter that should relieve my soul is far from me:
my children are desolate,
because the enemy prevailed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zion spreadeth forth her hands,
and there is none to comfort her:
the Lord hath commanded concerning Jacob,
that his adversaries should be round about him:
Jerusalem is as a menstruous woman among them.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I called for my lovers, but they deceived me:
my priests and mine elders gave up the ghost in the city,
while they sought their meat to relieve their souls.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They have heard that I sigh:
there is none to comfort me:
all mine enemies have heard of my trouble;
they are glad that thou hast done it:
thou wilt bring the day that thou hast called,
and they shall be like unto me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How hath the Lord covered the daughter of Zion
with a cloud in his anger,
and cast down from heaven unto the earth
the beauty of Israel,
and remembered not his footstool
in the day of his anger!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord hath swallowed up
all the habitations of Jacob,
and hath not pitied:
he hath thrown down in his wrath
the strong holds of the daughter of Judah;
he hath brought them down to the ground:
he hath polluted the kingdom
and the princes thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath cut off in his fierce anger
all the horn of Israel:
he hath drawn back his right hand
from before the enemy,
and he burned against Jacob like a flaming fire,
which devoureth round about.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath bent his bow like an enemy:
he stood with his right hand as an adversary,
and slew all that were pleasant to the eye
in the tabernacle of the daughter of Zion:
he poured out his fury like fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord was as an enemy:
he hath swallowed up Israel,
he hath swallowed up all her palaces:
he hath destroyed his strong holds,
and hath increased in the daughter of Judah
mourning and lamentation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And he hath violently taken away his tabernacle,
as if it were of a garden:
he hath destroyed his places of the assembly:
the Lord hath caused the solemn feasts
and sabbaths to be forgotten in Zion,
and hath despised in the indignation of his anger
the king and the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord hath cast off his altar,
he hath abhorred his sanctuary,
he hath given up into the hand of the enemy
the walls of her palaces;
they have made a noise in the house of the Lord,
as in the day of a solemn feast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord hath purposed to destroy
the wall of the daughter of Zion:
he hath stretched out a line,
he hath not withdrawn his hand from destroying:
therefore he made the rampart and the wall to lament;
they languished together.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The elders of the daughter of Zion
sit upon the ground, and keep silence:
they have cast up dust upon their heads;
they have girded themselves with sackcloth:
the virgins of Jerusalem hang down their heads to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mine eyes do fail with tears,
my bowels are troubled,
my liver is poured upon the earth,
for the destruction of the daughter of my people;
because the children and the sucklings
swoon in the streets of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say to their mothers,
Where is corn and wine?
when they swooned as the wounded
in the streets of the city,
when their soul was poured out
into their mothers’ bosom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What thing shall I take to witness for thee?
what thing shall I liken to thee,
O daughter of Jerusalem?
what shall I equal to thee, that I may comfort thee,
O virgin daughter of Zion?
for thy breach is great like the sea:
who can heal thee?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy prophets have seen vain and foolish things for thee:
and they have not discovered thine iniquity,
to turn away thy captivity;
but have seen for thee false burdens
and causes of banishment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All that pass by clap their hands at thee;
they hiss and wag their head at the daughter of Jerusalem,
saying, Is this the city that men call The perfection of beauty,
The joy of the whole earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
All thine enemies have opened their mouth against thee:
they hiss and gnash the teeth:
they say, We have swallowed her up:
certainly this is the day that we looked for;
we have found, we have seen it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord hath done that which he had devised;
he hath fulfilled his word
that he had commanded in the days of old:
he hath thrown down, and hath not pitied:
and he hath caused thine enemy to rejoice over thee,
he hath set up the horn of thine adversaries.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Arise, cry out in the night:
in the beginning of the watches
pour out thine heart like water
before the face of the Lord:
lift up thy hands toward him
for the life of thy young children,
that faint for hunger in the top of every street.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, O Lord, and consider
to whom thou hast done this.
Shall the women eat their fruit,
and children of a span long?
shall the priest and the prophet
be slain in the sanctuary of the Lord?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Thou hast called as in a solemn day
my terrors round about,
so that in the day of the Lord’s anger
none escaped nor remained:
those that I have swaddled and brought up
hath mine enemy consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am the man that hath seen affliction
by the rod of his wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath led me, and brought me into darkness,
but not into light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely against me is he turned;
he turneth his hand against me all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My flesh and my skin hath he made old;
he hath broken my bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath builded against me,
and compassed me with gall and travail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath set me in dark places,
as they that be dead of old.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath hedged me about, that I cannot get out:
he hath made my chain heavy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also when I cry and shout,
he shutteth out my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath inclosed my ways with hewn stone,
he hath made my paths crooked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He was unto me as a bear lying in wait,
and as a lion in secret places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath turned aside my ways, and pulled me in pieces:
he hath made me desolate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath bent his bow,
and set me as a mark for the arrow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath caused the arrows of his quiver
to enter into my reins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was a derision to all my people;
and their song all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath filled me with bitterness,
he hath made me drunken with wormwood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath also broken my teeth with gravel stones,
he hath covered me with ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And thou hast removed my soul far off from peace:
I forgat prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I said, My strength and my hope
is perished from the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text:
remembering mine affliction and my misery,
the wormwood and the gall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul hath them still in remembrance,
and is humbled in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This I recall to my mind,
therefore have I hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is of the Lord’s mercies that we are not consumed,
because his compassions fail not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are new every morning:
great is thy faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is my portion, saith my soul;
therefore will I hope in him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is good unto them that wait for him,
to the soul that seeketh him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is good that a man should both hope
and quietly wait for the salvation of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is good for a man that he bear the yoke in his youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sitteth alone and keepeth silence,
because he hath borne it upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He putteth his mouth in the dust;
if so be there may be hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He giveth his cheek to him that smiteth him:
he is filled full with reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will not cast off for ever:
speaker: Narrator

text:
but though he cause grief,
yet will he have compassion
according to the multitude of his mercies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he doth not afflict willingly
nor grieve the children of men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To crush under his feet
all the prisoners of the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to turn aside the right of a man
before the face of the most High,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to subvert a man in his cause,
the Lord approveth not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is he that saith, and it cometh to pass,
when the Lord commandeth it not?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of the mouth of the most High
proceedeth not evil and good?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wherefore doth a living man complain,
a man for the punishment of his sins?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us search and try our ways,
and turn again to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us lift up our heart with our hands
unto God in the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have transgressed and have rebelled:
thou hast not pardoned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou hast covered with anger, and persecuted us:
thou hast slain, thou hast not pitied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou hast covered thyself with a cloud,
that our prayer should not pass through.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou hast made us as the offscouring
and refuse in the midst of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: All our enemies have opened their mouths against us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear and a snare is come upon us,
desolation and destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mine eye runneth down with rivers of water
for the destruction of the daughter of my people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mine eye trickleth down, and ceaseth not,
without any intermission,
speaker: Narrator

text:
till the Lord look down,
and behold from heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mine eye affecteth mine heart
because of all the daughters of my city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mine enemies chased me sore,
like a bird, without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have cut off my life in the dungeon,
and cast a stone upon me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Waters flowed over mine head;
then I said, I am cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I called upon thy name, O Lord,
out of the low dungeon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou hast heard my voice:
hide not thine ear at my breathing, at my cry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou drewest near in the day that I called upon thee:
thou saidst, Fear not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, thou hast pleaded the causes of my soul;
thou hast redeemed my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, thou hast seen my wrong:
judge thou my cause.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou hast seen all their vengeance
and all their imaginations against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou hast heard their reproach, O Lord,
and all their imaginations against me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the lips of those that rose up against me,
and their device against me all the day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold their sitting down, and their rising up;
I am their musick.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Render unto them a recompence, O Lord,
according to the work of their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give them sorrow of heart,
thy curse unto them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Persecute and destroy them in anger
from under the heavens of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How is the gold become dim!
how is the most fine gold changed!
the stones of the sanctuary are poured out
in the top of every street.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The precious sons of Zion,
comparable to fine gold,
how are they esteemed as earthen pitchers,
the work of the hands of the potter!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even the sea monsters draw out the breast,
they give suck to their young ones:
the daughter of my people is become cruel,
like the ostriches in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tongue of the sucking child
cleaveth to the roof of his mouth for thirst:
the young children ask bread,
and no man breaketh it unto them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They that did feed delicately are desolate in the streets:
they that were brought up in scarlet embrace dunghills.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the punishment of the iniquity of the daughter of my people
is greater than the punishment of the sin of Sodom,
that was overthrown as in a moment,
and no hands stayed on her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her Nazarites were purer than snow,
they were whiter than milk,
they were more ruddy in body than rubies,
their polishing was of sapphire:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They that be slain with the sword are better
than they that be slain with hunger:
for these pine away,
stricken through for want of the fruits of the field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hands of the pitiful women have sodden their own children:
they were their meat in the destruction of the daughter of my people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord hath accomplished his fury;
he hath poured out his fierce anger,
and hath kindled a fire in Zion,
and it hath devoured the foundations thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The kings of the earth, and all the inhabitants of the world,
would not have believed that the adversary and the enemy
should have entered into the gates of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the sins of her prophets,
and the iniquities of her priests,
that have shed the blood of the just in the midst of her,
speaker: Narrator

text:
they have wandered as blind men in the streets,
they have polluted themselves with blood,
so that men could not touch their garments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cried unto them, Depart ye; it is unclean;
depart, depart, touch not:
when they fled away and wandered,
they said among the heathen, They shall no more sojourn there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The anger of the Lord hath divided them;
he will no more regard them:
they respected not the persons of the priests,
they favoured not the elders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for us, our eyes as yet failed for our vain help:
in our watching we have watched
for a nation that could not save us.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Our persecutors are swifter than the eagles of the heaven:
they pursued us upon the mountains,
they laid wait for us in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The breath of our nostrils,
the anointed of the Lord,
was taken in their pits,
of whom we said,
Under his shadow we shall live among the heathen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rejoice and be glad, O daughter of Edom,
that dwellest in the land of Uz;
the cup also shall pass through unto thee:
thou shalt be drunken,
and shalt make thyself naked.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Remember, O Lord, what is come upon us:
consider, and behold our reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our inheritance is turned to strangers,
our houses to aliens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We are orphans and fatherless,
our mothers are as widows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have drunken our water for money;
our wood is sold unto us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our necks are under persecution:
we labour, and have no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have given the hand to the Egyptians,
and to the Assyrians, to be satisfied with bread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our fathers have sinned, and are not;
and we have borne their iniquities.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Servants have ruled over us:
there is none that doth deliver us out of their hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We gat our bread with the peril of our lives
because of the sword of the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our skin was black like an oven
because of the terrible famine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They ravished the women in Zion,
and the maids in the cities of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Princes are hanged up by their hand:
the faces of elders were not honoured.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They took the young men to grind,
and the children fell under the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The elders have ceased from the gate,
the young men from their musick.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The joy of our heart is ceased;
our dance is turned into mourning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crown is fallen from our head:
woe unto us, that we have sinned!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this our heart is faint;
for these things our eyes are dim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because of the mountain of Zion, which is desolate,
the foxes walk upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou, O Lord, remainest for ever;
thy throne from generation to generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wherefore dost thou forget us for ever,
and forsake us so long time?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn thou us unto thee, O Lord, and we shall be turned;
renew our days as of old.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But thou hast utterly rejected us;
thou art very wroth against us.
speaker: Narrator
